content.description: Same start as White Lightning, move up and traverse across the obvious ledge.  At the end of the traverse, use the pocket to move up and to the right to complete the topout on the far right of the boulder.
content.protection: Use pads, especially for the crux move near the pocket.
content.location: Same start as White Lightning.

content.description: THE best V2 in the whole boulder field. Stand start low in the white-lined crack feature. Move up through a few jugs, then tech the crux using a variety of small shallow pockets to an easy mantle.
content.location: On the left of the main trail in between Slopey Seconds and Like The Dickens.

content.description: Sit start on right side of the boulder with right hand on a small pinch. Move up to a large slopey sidepull, then follow crack feature up and left to the same mantle ledge as Thumb Wrestling. The right arete is off, but you wouldn't use it anyway.
content.location: Just right of Thumb Wrestling, shares the same topout.

content.description: The lines on this boulder were hiding for a long time--they may have been done at some point in the past, given that they're not that difficult, but the climbing is quite amazing and beautiful, though very spicy at perhaps 25 feet. Standing in the middle of the warm-up area (with Thumb Wrestling to your right), look up the hill and left--you'll see a tall boulder jutting out of the rhodos. Walk past the boulder below the rhodo line, and then cut back and right, ducking through the rhodos until you arrive at this quite tall boulder. All of the problems on this boulder are quite tall on lovely stone...a fall would almost certainly mean serious injury. From left to right, the arete is perhaps V1, with an easy exit mid-way if it gets too scary. The face immediately right is perhaps v3 with the most committing moves up in the no-fall zone. To the right, the system of flakes through the dihedral is very easy (V0?) to the lip, but the lip mantle is a bit tricky and perhaps V3, and a fall would be very unpleasant.
content.protection: Lots of pads, but they won't do much for you beyond the no-fall zone.

content.description: Start matched on a jug on the detached block and then make long reaches and balancy moves through the awkward top out.
content.location: Furthest established route on the Horny boulder. Climbs through two distinct X shaped seams.

content.description: Sit start on the lowest seam. Climb the diagonal seams up the face finding decent footholds as well. Top out, and then down climb left.
content.location: At the intersection where the trail to the Slopey Seconds boulder and Croc Hunter Boulder split. Problem is on your left when you approach from the entrance.

content.description: Sit start matched in vertical seam. Use a variety of techniques to reach the ledge and mantel. Continue to topout.
content.location: ~10 yards past Like The Dickens on the blue ribboned main trail, the Thumb Wrestling boulder will be on your left.

content.description: Start right on a good pinch, and feet in a hard-not-to-dab spot. Move through pinches and crimps to the easier jug haul which leads up and over the point A tall proud line with a bad landing.
content.location: Right side of the face in between the Dickens and Six Pack of Slabs boulders when. facing uphill.

content.description: Easy first couple moves up to a mono pocket on the left and a big reach to the top.
content.protection: Crash pad wedged into the corridor

content.description: Start matched on the L shaped jug flake in the middle of the face. Power up through slopey crimpers to the top and mantle out.
content.location: On the Croc Hunter boulder, left of Croc Hunter. Stand start to the classic Stingray.

content.description: Sit start on obvious sloping jug. Use crazy core tension to climb the side pull system up and right to the jug of the stand start and finish from there.
content.location: On the Croc Hunter boulder, down and left in the pit.

content.description: Start left hand on the lowest sloper on the lip, and right hand on good undercling. Make blind moves up amazing sloper pockets to a casual topout using the left arete.
content.location: After passing Thumb Wrestling on your left, keep going for another 20 yards to find a faint trail scrabling uphill towards the cliff line. Follow this all the way to the cliff to find this boulder almost touching it.

content.description: Climb the blunt arete that resembles the namesake continent. Start on a good crimp line. Bump to the arete, and then figure out high feet and the right hand sequence to top out way above your crash pad.
content.location: Down the hill from Like the Dickens. On the right side of the overhanging arete-face. The line right of Lion Turtle.

content.description: Start with a left heel and hands matched on a jug. Bump over to the right leaning crack feature and continue to climb up it till you can find some ok feet before reaching some positive overhanging jugs towards the top. From there, traverse right until you can top out.
content.protection: 1 or 2 pads. The starting area and the top out area are above some large uneven rocks.
content.location: From Like the Dickens go around to the right towards the cliff face. You should see the obvious curving crack feature.

content.description: Climb up the left side of the beautiful white slab perched on the sketchy edge. Ideally don't fall, because if you pop too far off then you will plummet another good 10 feet past the small ledge to the ground. Good holds throughout though. This problem provides an awesome view from the copout.
content.protection: A pad and one or two spotters
content.location: After walking about 25 yards past Like the Dickens, look to your left for a faint trail leading towards the cliff through a rhodo jungle. Pass the Rattle Battle problem and climb the small ledge to get established underneath this beautiful white slab.

content.description: Start as low as you can on the slopey lip, with a good left hand and right hand under the roof. Get a left heel on and start slappin your way to the point.
content.location: Off to the right of the blue ribboned main trail.

content.description: Sit start and work your hands up the slopey feature. The first move is the toughest.
Stand start on pocket and side pull, climb straight up slab.
content.location: Slabby rounded arete next to Dickens boulder, just outside the corridor between this boulder and Dickens boulder.

content.description: Start with a good left high sloping rail and a decent right hand side-pull, smear with good feet and then bump up to the juggy arete you will follow to the top.
content.location: On the Trailside Boulder on the face facing the Croc Hunter boulder.

content.description: Start same as normal, but do not use the detached boulder for feet. Makes it harder and a bit awkward, but its still amazing!

Sit start on the right side of the arete with left hand on pointy undercling and right wherever. Using the detached boulder to your left for feet, maneuver up the overhanging arete using holds on both sides.
content.location: The first boulder you will see when hiking into the Main area following the blue ribbons.

content.description: Hand and fist jams in SW PA? Look no further! Follow the crack up to an easy top out. You probably could find some jugs in or around the crack, but come on... use the hand jams!
content.location: To the left of Lion Turtle.

content.description: From the pre-guide, "Classic Coll's Cove highball slab! Start of blank face with left foot on a good seam. Keep finding hidden feet till a crux at the top." Trust me, bring a strong mental game for this one, but the immaculate gritstone slab is well worth the reward.
content.protection: Definitely will want a pad. Pretty big falls from the top, Maybe 2 or 3 to make it super comfortable.
content.location: On the huge face of the massive boulder right behind the Like the Dickens boulder, and in front of the cliff-line and Snake in the Hand Slab.

content.description: Sit start on your choice of crimps. Move up to bad crimps, use more worse crimps, and hit the top. If you didn't get it by now, you better be good on crimps for this one!
content.location: Follow the blue ribboned main trail all the way to the back.

content.description: Sit start low on an obvious diagonal rail near a tree and move up and left along the feature to a technical award top out.A V3+ (suggested) variation: Start from the low left-most crack and move right along to the original start of Penetrating the Weakness, then follow the line.
content.location: The line to the left of Horny that follows the obvious diagonal feature

content.description:
The description I saw for this problem gives it a V4, but it felt incredibly soft. I'm leaving it as is until others give their input.

 Start on the obvious underclings in the middle of the left face. Shoot up and mantel the obvious feature about halfway up the face and then continue the easy face climb to the top.
content.location: Down the hill from the White Lightning Boulder.

content.description: The low start to Stevie Wonder starts with right hand in a double pocket, left hand on the arete. Slap up blindly to the sloper pockets of Stevie Wonder and topout.
content.location: low start to Stevie Wonder

content.description: Start from the same jug Snake starts on, but head straight up through pockets. Topout might be dirty -- it might be best to just drop down after you are fully standing on the slab (judge for yourself)
content.location: Shares start with Snake

content.description: Start low on good holds. Climb the tall beautiful face on a series of slopey crimp rails. The aretes are off on both sides, but its still pure.
content.location: Looking at Like the Dickens, turn around and walk ~15 yards downhill on a faint trail.

content.description: Start as low as you can on the rail feature under the roof, with a right heel on. Move into crux holds, fire a big shouldery move, try not to dab, then mantle onto face. No topout necessary, just be standing on your feet. Many variations exist on this boulder and will be described in better detail in the future.
content.location: Around Slopey Seconds the Main trail will split, follow blue ribbons to the right. Continue for ~50 yards, passing White Lightning to your left. LTD will on your right.

content.description: Sit start and climb the right side of the striking white gritstone arete.
content.location: Next to The Switch problem on the opposite boulder that forms the slot which The Switch is in.

content.description: Start matched on sloper dish, slap up blunt arete up and left to the top, mantle.
content.location: Blunt arete on the right side of the downhill face of Mr Yuk boulder.

content.description: Start on the jug to the right of the sassafras tree, and then use jugs on the overhanging face to through over the top of the bulge to get a solid hold (crux) before topping out.
content.location: On the boulder to the left of the Thumb Wrestling Boulder as you follow the trail towards the Oatmeal Boulder. This problem is the rightmost problem on the downhill facing face of this boulder.

content.description: Climb the dihedral feature to a tricky topout. Fun stemming movements at the beginning culminate in a big reach for a sloper before the topout.
content.location: This problem is located on the right side of the boulder down hill about 50 yards to theft of the Croc Hunter Boulder when your back is facing the cliff-line.

content.description: Sit start on awkward sharp holds. Bump up to the immaculate iron crimp/pinch hold, and then mantle up onto the somewhat sloping ledge. The topout is easy after standing up on the mantle ledge, but the mantle itself is full value.
content.location: To the left of High and Far Out, on the next bigger boulder downhill and slightly left of the Croc Hunter boulder.

content.description: Start on a rounded flake and move up to the interesting roof encounter and mantle/pull over it to the slab. Get your extra credit by going all the way to the top.
content.location: To the left of Like the Dickens below the roof/lip.

content.description: Start low on blunt arete with bad feet. Climb up and left through slopers to the top.
content.location: Around slopey seconds, the main trail splits. Follow more blue ribbons downhill for ~20 yards to find this classic boulder.

content.description: Stand start and finesse your way up a deceptively hard crack feature which doesn't really allow for jamming but requires the use of sloping crimps.
content.location: The obvious crack-esque feature between South America and Africa

content.description: Start on the feet of Bhante Pema and climb slightly right of the Bhante Pema start, on the blunt arete with pockets. After a couple moves, make some long, tense moves way right to a seam. Follow the seam up and left to rejoin with the high seam on Bhante. Starting with right hand in the seam is perhaps soft v9 (originally done as Buny Puma). A sit start from the right may also have been done at V11.
Stand start on the "turtle back rock" with hands on the reach starting pockets. Campus out to the edge of the "hatchet" and then topout on the point.
content.protection: Landing is a little sketchy. One or two pads and a spotter should be good
content.location: To the right of the trail as you are approaching Slopey Seconds. Located between the Reallyreally Good Boulder and Sloper Seconds. The climb is closer to the hillside. Look for an obvious pointed rock near an overhang about 30 feet or so off the trail.

content.description: Climb the slab to the right of Croc Hunter (V6).
content.location: Croc Hunter Boulder

content.description: Start with your left in an undercling pocket and your right hand getting whatever friction you can manage, stand up to get a sloper rail with your right. Tech your way straight up the slopers with high feet, mantling, and trust in friction.
content.location: Very large boulder down the hill from White Lightning. Has an enormous slab face on the side facing Mr. Yuk boulder. Seen from White Lightning boulder, has a detached block and vertical cracks. Lots of variations to be done here.

content.description: The "little black" project has fallen to local legend Joel Brady. Start low with both hands in good underclings. Climb up and right to a good vertical seam, then hit the top and topout.
content.location: Just left of the "big black" project on the Big Black boulder. This boulder is down hill from The Dickens boulder about 30 yards.

content.description: The business is all of three moves, approximately two feet off the ground. Start to the right of Like the Dickens and The Snake (see PDF topo), back in the little cave. Pull through some very tiny holds, utilizing a key toe hook out left. Join The Snake and exit up and right. A difficult problem to grade--it has seen a flash.
Nice easy highball. Low crux after second or third move leads to jugs along a large flake.
content.protection: Crash pads. Top out but it's a pain to get back down through the bushes.

content.description: This area hosts the best of the best at Coll's Cove! So many classics, so many more to find and do! The main area refers to all the boulders scattered beneath the cliff line. The rock here is "pa gritstone", which is more similar to LRC in Chattanooga than Coopers Rock in WV.
